learning_outcomes.description: Use mathematical techniques suitable for solving large-scale problems in operations research
Effectively communicate solutions to operations research problems

assessments.task_description:
To help ensure you are using a suitable paper for your major project, you will fill in a short template for your project.  There will also be a very short in class presentation (5 to 8 minutes) describing the problem and how you plan to solve it.

Students are encouraged to do projects in a group of 2 or 3 students.  Not all students in a group need to present for this assesment task.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Email your review to the Course Coordinator
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students must upload a short video presentation (8 to 12 minutes long) about their paper and implementation.  This presentation is a valuable opportunity to clarify your ideas prior to submitting your report the following week.

All students in the group need to present for roughly the same time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Project
assessments.task_description:
The major project will require each student, or group of students, to choose a recent substantial paper in Operations Research and implement an algorithm described in the paper and write a short report. The paper chosen will need to be approved by the Course Coordinator.

Students are encouraged to do projects in a group of 2 or 3 students.

For MATH7202, the report will be required to cover issues that might be faced when implementing the methods in industry.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Email your report to the Course Coordinator
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The Practical Exam will be invigilated on-campus.  It will involve modeling and solving one or more problems using one or more of the computer-based methods covered in the course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description: The Theory Exam will be invigilated on-campus.  The exam will cover the theoretical content of the course and modelling applications. The exam is open book - you will be able to bring in your notes to use during the exam but you will not have computer access.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures/Applied Classes

The five hours of contact each week will be highly interactive. Some of this time will be spent discussing the mathematical foundations of the techniques we are using but we will often link this to particular applications and models. All content will be recorded.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures/Applied Classes The five hours of contact each week will be highly interactive. Some of this time will be spent discussing the mathematical foundations of the techniques we are using but we will often link this to particular applications and models. All content will be recorded.
